info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 01 at 5:54PM MDT until July 01 at 7:15PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING FOR THE HERMITS PEAK AND CALF CANYON BURN SCAR REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 715 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR NORTHWESTERN SAN MIGUEL COUNTY... At 554 PM MDT, While thunderstorms have come to an end now, earlier thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall over the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. Between 0.25 and 1.25 inches of rain are estimated to have fallen. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will initially impact the Sapello River, Beaver Creek, Porvenir Canyon and Gallinas Creek drainage areas. Any debris flows that develop can consist of ash, soot, rock, mud, logs, vegetation and other loose materials within the torrent of water. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding in and around the southern parts of the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. Some locations that are most likely to experience flash flooding include... El Porvenir, San Ignacio, Gallinas, Sapello, and other nearby villages. This includes the following highways... State Road 266 between Mile Markers 0 and 6. State Road 65 between Mile Markers 1 and 14. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Do not camp along streams and rivers. Remain alert when hiking in steep, narrow canyons. Know where you are relative to low spots and drainages. This is a life threatening situation. Heavy rainfall will cause extensive and severe flash flooding of creeks, streams and ditches in the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. Severe debris flows can also be anticipated across roads. Roads and driveways may be washed away in places. If you encounter flood waters, climb to safety.
